introduction.p: Begin with a set of xy-axes. Draw the vector \uvec{x}_0 = (3,0) with its tail at the origin, and then draw the vector \uvec{p} = (2,1) with its tail at the head of \uvec{x}_0.

task.p: Consider the expression \uvec{x} = \uvec{x}_0 + t\uvec{p} in the parameter t. Think of \uvec{x} as a variable vector using different values of t, \uvec{x} evaluates to different vectors. Draw the vector \uvec{x} for t=1 on your diagram with its tail at the origin and using a dashed line for the shaft of the arrow. Then do the same for t=2, t=-1, t=1/2, t=-3.

aside.title: Note
aside.p: You shouldn't have to compute any coordinates to be able to draw these vectors, you should be able to just use your initial diagram of \uvec{x}_0 and \uvec{p} to know where \uvec{x} ends up for these various values of t.

task.p: Suppose you continued sketching in the different possible \uvec{x} vectors forever, using every possible value for the parameter t. What shape would be traced out by all of the points at the heads of the different versions of \uvec{x}?

introduction.p: The equation x - 2y = 3 defines a line \ell in \R^2. We can also view this equation as a system of linear equations. Its solution requires one parameter.

task.p: Verify that the point (4,1/2) lies on \ell. Then determine the value of the parameter t so that \uvec{x} = (4,1/2).

introduction.p: Consider the two planes \Pi_1\amp\colon\;\; 2x - y + z = 3, \amp \Pi_2\amp\colon\;\; x + 3y - 2z = -1 in \R^3.

statement.p: Verify that \Pi_1 and \Pi_2 are not parallel.
Two nonparallel planes must intersect in a line. Describe the line of intersection of \Pi_1 and \Pi_2 in the form \uvec{x} = \uvec{x}_0 + t\uvec{p}.

hint.p: Any point in the intersection must lie on both planes at once. That is, any point in the intersection must be a solution to the system of equations formed by the two plane equations.

introduction.p: The equation x - y + 2z = -3 defines a plane in \R^3. We can also view this equation as a system of linear equations.

task.p:
Similarly to , determine vectors \uvec{x}_0, \uvec{p}_1, and \uvec{p}_2 so that
\uvec{x} = \left[\begin{smallmatrix}x\\y\\z\end{smallmatrix}\right] = \uvec{x}_0 + s\uvec{p}_1 + t\uvec{p}_2
describes all solutions to the equation (and hence all points on the plane).
Verify that the point (-1,4,1) lies on this plane.
Then determine the values of the parameters s and t so that \uvec{x} = (-1,4,1).

activity.p: Draw a grid over the xy-plane, with a vertical line at each integer value of x and a horizontal line at each integer value of y. Then draw \uvec{e}_1 and \uvec{e}_2 on your diagram.
What does the decomposition (3,2) = 3\uvec{e}_1 + 2\uvec{e_2} look like on your grid?

Draw a grid over the xy-plane as follows: at each integer value along the x-axis, draw both a vertical line and a slant line parallel to the line y=x. Then draw \uvec{u} = (1,1) and \uvec{e}_2 on your diagram.
What does the decomposition (3,2) = 3\uvec{u} + (-1)\uvec{e}_2 look like on your grid?

The set of all solutions to the homogeneous equation x - 2y + 3z = 0 forms a plane in \R^3. We can solve this equation by assigning parameters y=s and z=t, so that all solutions can be described parametrically by (x,y,z) = s(2,1,0) + t(-3,0,1). Discuss how the vectors \uvec{p}_1 = (2,1,0) and \uvec{p}_2 = (-3,0,1) create a grid on the plane defined by x - 2y + 3z = 0, similarly to the grids you worked with in
and .

aside.title: Note
aside.p: Since the plane equation x - 2y + 3z = 0 is homogeneous, this plane passes through the origin.

statement.p:
Determine the point of intersection of the line \ell, described parametrically below left, and the plane \Pi, described algebraically below right.
\ell\amp\colon\;\; \uvec{x} = (2,0,3) + t(-1,1,1) \amp \Pi\amp\colon\;\; 2x+y-3z=7

hint.p: The point of intersection is simultaneously on the line and on the plane.

statement.p:
Set up a system of equations whose solution is the point of intersection of the line \ell and the plane \Pi, described parametrically below.
\ell\amp\colon\;\; \uvec{x} = (2,0,3) + t(-1,1,1) \amp \Pi\amp\colon\;\; \uvec{x} = (3,1,0) + r(1,1,1) + s(3,0,2)

hint.p: The point of intersection is simultaneously on the line and on the plane.
